div.p: The miscellany of fourteen texts in CCCC MS 288, dating to c. 1200, has no obvious unifying theme. The book opens with a number of letters of Alan of Tewkesbury OSB (d. 1202), followed by an anonymous liturgical tract on church offices and a tract on the Mass by Richard the Premonstratensian (fl. late twelfth century). Parts of the book contain apocrypha of the New Testament such as the Gospel of Nicodemus and the De ortu beatae Mariae et infantia saluatoris. Other parts contain prophetic texts such as some by Hildegard of Bingen OSB (1098-1179) and the De initio et fine saeculi (Revelations) of pseudo-Methodius. The book belonged to N de Sandwico (Sandwich, Kent), a monk of the cathedral priory of Christ Church, Canterbury, and can perhaps be identified with an item in the early fourteenth-century library catalogue by Henry of Eastry.
